Comment: New Mexico has a very high Hispanic population (almost 60%) and a relatively high percentage of Native Americans (over 10%). Both of these numbers are higher than most other Western states, and both of these demographics vote disproportionately Democratic. As a result, New Mexico has been a liberal-leaning state for a long time.  Colorado, on the other hand, was a solidly red state until the 2000s. Its shift leftward began in that decade, when it began attracting a large population of transplants from other states that were disproportionately young, more diverse, educated, and liberal-leaning, drawn to Colorado's outdoorsy culture. A lot of what makes western states red is that they're overwhelmingly rural, and rural voters tend to vote Republican. But as western cities grow, those states can shift quickly.

Comment: But college doesn't teach critical thinking.   It may offer it as a course, but that's not the same thing as inculcating critical thinking skills.  There is no correlation between a college education and the ability to think critically, in an open, honest way.  IMO, it's more likely to observe genuine critical thinking in a plumber or carpenter or other practical problem solver, than from a social sciences graduate.  The core of critical thinking is to *consider more than one point of view*.  This is very much an anti-pattern in many modern curricula, where much "critical thinking" is actually indoctrination and the required acceptance of dogma.  College education can instill groupthink, doctrinaire thinking, tribalism. There's a reward system in place for going along with the group, over contrary thinking.      **The results speak for themselves.**

Comment: Can you find me unbiased data that shows, conclusively that college education improves critical thinking skills?  A lot of this is conjecture, yes. But these are political judgements.  Regarding vaccines, a different hypothesis is that college graduates are more likely to accept the word of authority figures.  Here in Australia, the most accepting group of people of \*both\* covid vaccination and severe government lockdowns were left-leaning university educated people.  Interestingly, its this cohort which also are most resistant to vaccinations in general. Many university educated people, particularly women, are very big in to woo-woo and "alternative" medicine.  So, clearly, "critical thinking" is not necessarilly a product of a university education.  But people who are university educated say it is...

Comment: I‚Äôll adjust my position then. I‚Äôve looked up studies, and college doesn‚Äôt seem to neither help nor hurt critical thinking ability. Depending on degree, it does, however, teach you how to research; how to find information, vet sources, create and test hypotheses, etc. That‚Äôs an additional skillset that most high-school educated individuals lack. I‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find anyone who completely trusts ALL authority figures or experts. That said, trusting experts is a heuristic that is helpful, as experts are generally trustworthy (you can push on this point all you want, but society as a whole does lean on them for almost everything like medicine, and going to the moon, etc.). So college may not increase critical thinking ability per se, but it absolutely is not ‚Äúindoctrination.‚Äù This is evident in that research is rooted in epistemology, so if your degree requires some level of researching, it requires you to be critical of your sources of information. So I‚Äôll narrow my claim; college graduates whose degrees are in the sciences or other research-heavy domains, rather than technical, are more likely to be better at vetting sources, and hence less susceptible to conspiracy theories. As to your assertion that ‚Äúmany university educated people, particularly women‚Äù are into alternative medicine, that‚Äôs just based entirely on vibes.. I could not find any data on that whatsoever.  Also, here‚Äôs the [Study](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5248629/) it has a sample size of around 4,000 participants. The correlation between susceptibility to conspiracy theories and education is in the data. The authors are hypothesizing on what the mediator could be.

Comment: Really appreciate your thoughtful takes. I agree with what you‚Äôve laid out here, but I also venture to say there is simply as much correlation as causation with education and political alignment in our country. Forgive me as I have only anecdotal evidence & what I would consider objective sociological viewpoints and also little to no concrete evidence nor research, but I think there is something to be said about those who, at some point in adolescence, find themselves on a likely trajectory to attend college and how it can shape one‚Äôs mental capacity to more align with right or left politics. It‚Äôs around what, age 10 or 11 now - maybe even earlier - that children are tested, gauged, and assigned college-likelihoodedness and subsequently are impacted on many levels that can really affect the personality developments that feed into eventual politics. As a classic example, children in lower-income areas with high potential for conventional college and so on success tend to have access to programs that not only differentiate them from their peers in a positive light but allow them more security and access to things like trusted adults, safe spaces, positive friendships, even things as essential as food security. This can allow these individuals the emotional capacity to develop a more altruistic nature, nuanced understandings of others‚Äô experiences, and a sense for selflessness - whereas those sorts of ideals can seem like impossible luxuries to their peers with zero resources, a sense of academic abandonment due to a test score, and an entrapment in a survival mindset. I‚Äôm not calling to disagree with our existing methods necessarily, but I think we have found ourselves in a political landscape where the bipartisan is existing within and capitalizing upon an incredibly complex divide and it‚Äôs far too nuanced to really boil down to anything black and white, no pun intended.
Author: shezapisces
